Annotation_Descrip: Poe 2019 (unpub) convincingly argues that this is very likely a junior synonym of aliniger. Because images presented in type description don't support that paper's stated diagnosis, and because genetically very similar (indeed paraphyletic) to aliniger, I am proceeding to score this as LUMP. Also, DLM collected a paratype of this species (MCZ-R 190696) and found no reason to suspect it was not a typical aliniger.

DLM treating Aruba, Curacao, Bonaire, Isla Blanquilla as Leeward Antilles rather than as Lesser Antilles. Note that islands are predominantly faunistically South American (e.g., van Buurt 2010), but that author implies older Antillean links. For anoles, two species are of Lesser Antilles stock (bonairensis, blanquillanus) and one from South American stock (lineatus).

Annotation_Descrip: Rivas.et.al.2012 suggest that the holotype of gibbiceps came from Jamaica, not Caracas, and suggest that it belongs to lineatopus, opalinus, or grahami. I don't think it's any of those, or from Jamaica, based on their Figure 6. It seems like a mainland Draconura clade anole, probably in the chrysolepis clade (e.g., planiceps). Snout way too short to be from Jamaica. Limbs too thin and gangly. Too much of a neck. Hard to identify from photo - needs to be examined. Poe 2019 (unpublished) recommends this to be considered a nomen dubium.

DLM personal observations of morphology (size and shape), coloration, habitat use, and behavior suggest this is a trunk anole, not trunk-crown. In these regards it is very similar to distichus complex. Lister 1976 (Evolution 30:659-676) also considers opalinus to be a trunk anole.
Note Ruibal 1964 is basis for Williams and Rand assignment to ground ecomorph (in Rodriguez-Schettino et al 2010)

Annotation_Descrip: See comments in Pavon.Vazquez.et.al.2014 on how duellmani may be sunk into pygmaeus. I'm not aware of published data on pygmaeus specimens other than the holotype.

Poe 2019 (unpublished) highlights problems with current taxonomic delineation of quaggulus with respect to humilis (e.g., Phillips et al. 2015). See also Kohler et al. 2015. Poe 2019 suspects the name quaggulus will survive revision of the group, so retaining as NS for now, even though boundaries poorly defined with respect to humilis.
region.Poe.et.al.2017.mod: Upper Central America, Lower Central America
ecomorph.DLM.notes: Losos 2009 assignment by extension (contained within Losos's humilis)

ecomorph.DLM.notes: DLM personal observations of morphology (size and shape), coloration, habitat use, and behavior suggest this is a trunk anole, not trunk-crown. In these regards it is very similar to distichus complex.

Annotation_Descrip: I have doubts about distinctness of this taxon from pentaprion (types of both are from Colombia). See email to Steve Poe 2019.12.28; accordingly some doubts about whether Restrepo.et.al.2017 sulcifrons is indeed that taxon or should be pentaprion. Myers 1971 has a useful discussion of this taxon. Lots of recent records and photos of sulcifrons in Colombian inventories and guides (e.g., Suarez et al. 2014; Torres and Quinones 2019).
region.Poe.et.al.2017.notes: DLM - see pentaprion comments

Annotation_Descrip: Poe 2019 (unpublished) convincingly argues that island-endemic A. utilensis should be considered a junior synonym of (nearby mainland) A. beckeri. I am retaining only as LUMP_P because of potential utility in recognizing this island population as an independent evolutionary unit. However, this is not done in many other taxa, so may wish to synonymize for consistency.
region.Poe.et.al.2017.notes: Treating at satellite endemic, because Isla de Utila part of continental shelf
ecomorph.DLM.notes: Losos 2009 assignment by extension (Losos's pentaprion presumed to apply to this member of same clade); note that DLM assigned to "m.twig" even though on island, because very recent member of mainland pentaprion clade)
Losos 2009 referred all of the Phenacosaurus clade to "Twig anoles, some quite large"

Annotation_Descrip: DLM accepts Poe's 2019 recommendation to sink viridius into chlorodius (i.e., LUMP). Note - Poe 2019 (unpublished) tentatively accepts chlorodius as valid (i.e., distinct from coelestinus) based on relatively deep mtDNA split and cohesive geography (former eastern, latter western South Paleoisland of Hispaniola). DLM tentatively adopting Poe's suggestion, allowing though that the mtDNA divergence needn't indicate a species boudary.
ecomorph.DLM.notes: split from coelestinus by Kohler and Hedges 2016
